Emma is Jane Austen's most inaccessible and most stuffy story, told badly.

I think that this movie was reasonably bad. It's kinda weird that now the Olsen twins are 13 and have boyfriends and all. I didn't enjoy them at all when they were little kids on Full House. Anyway, the casting was terrible and the movie was not even a little bit funny. I kind of got confused between all the switching places and their names. It's just kind of a lousy version of It Takes Two.

This movie should not be compared to "The Sting", or other caper/heist/con game films. What makes it such a terrible movie experience is its shallow approach to relationships, deceit and trust. It's also a weak critique of psychiatry, given that the female protagonist is a shrink who is so easily deceived and then reacts in such a primitive manner in the finale. One might wonder if Mr Mamet had a positive experience in therapy to present it in such a poor light. Highly, strongly not recommended!

almost every review of this movie I'd seen was pretty good. It's not pretty good, it's actually pretty bad, though not terrible. The Judy Garland character could have been tolerable, but she ended up being quite annoying. Somewhere along the line, I've grown tired of brooding, overbearing, overacting Van Heflin, at least in the early 40's. Judy's singing is bad, and the film missed a great opportunity by showing too much of their relationship. I gave it a 3.

MULHOLLAND DRIVE made me the definitive fan of David Lynch. He's a modern genius, but his "genius" is questionable with his easy to follow storyline and sunny sets in THE STRAIGHT STORY. It was quite a disappointment to me, as I was expecting something more from him. While this is not the worst, it's a film that should be avoided. Late Richard Farnsworth's performance is the only redeeming feature of this film.

There's something terrible about the fact that a movie made in 1934 can be inferior to every Tarzan movie that followed it, including the lackluster and uninteresting 1980s piece Greystoke. Once the viewer gets past the first three scenes, which are admittedly entertaining, Tarzan and his Mate becomes a slog, offering few action, humor, or romance. Maureen O'Sullivan is unimpressive and unattractive as Jane and barely holds the movie together. Weismuller is disappointing as well. Not recommended.

Not a good martial arts film. Fight scenes were poor. Michel Qissi did a terrible job directing his first film without Van Damme. Story didn't work with the use of foul language and too much blood. Screenwriter Jeanette Francessca has a bad line to the story that doesn't work. It wouldn't be great to see something else from her in the same genre. She dislikes the art and having weak women prominent. It was definitely not worth watching. I don't recommend the film to any drama and martial arts lovers.

"Moonstruck" is one of the worst films ever. I regret buying that film on DVD! The movie is about a New York widow (Cher) who falls in love with her boyfriend's (Danny Aiello) annoying brother (Nicholas Cage) who works at a bakery. I'm disappointed that Cher won an Oscar for that movie. Nicholas Cage and Danny Aiello are terrible, too. The direction from Norman Jewison (who directed "Fiddler On The Roof") is horrible. "Moonstruck" is a terrible movie that no one should see or waste their time laughing at. A waste of time!

This movie re-wrote film history in every way, or so they say. Many people do care about the flaws in this movie, and criticism abounds. Every amazing aspect of the movie is easily overshadowed by its many flaws. It is an extremely mediocre movie, and I bet many of us will see much better films again. I've seen it a few times, and I still find it underwhelming every time, with a feeling of disappointment which is hard to shake off. One to forget, I'd say.

I found this film to be a dreadful study of a family in crisis. When Leo, the oldest announces that he is HIV+, the reactions of the family members alone and with each other were both off-putting and yet bizarre.

I have never seen a family that was as physically disgusting as this one; nor one as likely to whisper insults at each other. I didn't understand why the family felt that the youngest couldn't handle the news, but once past that difficult part, I found this a thoroughly disappointing film.

Negative marks to Cesar Montano for reviving the Cebuano movie! Panaghoy sa Suba is very disappointing -- it has no drama, no action, no romance, and scenes that will make you yawn.

While the story is not that original (a love triangle -- or make a four-cornered-love, Japanese occupation, rebellion, American as lord), its presentation is something lackluster, especially it uses its original language -- bisaya for the Filipino, nipongo for the Japanese and English for the American.

This movie will go as one of this year's worst Pinoy movies.

Don't watch this!

A new, underwhelming way to experience Goldsworthy's work, Rivers and Tides forces fans to see his work in motion. Watching Goldsworthy build his pieces makes one realize the monotony of every stone, leaf, and thorn that he uses. Goldsworthy explains how the monotonous flow of life, the rivers, and the tides inspires and affects his work. Although, I was not pleased that the film covered so many of Goldsworthy's pieces (even the snowballs), I do feel it was excessively long. The film makers did a terrible job of animating Goldsworthy's work, and created a dull film that was a burden to watch.

This is a comedy based on national stereotypes, no doubt. If you don't leave away pretending you know or you care what Communism was about and how real Russians or Brits are, if you don't accept and are hurt by the conventions, you can't have fun with this film. Nicole Kidman is not at her best, not sexy, moving and funny. Ben Chaplin fails to avoid being completely out-shadowed by Nicole, and the rest of the cast does poor work as well. The final is not moving, and illogical - movie logics, of course. Not worth watching, if you don't accept the rules of the game.

"Amazing Grace" has a dull feel to it as it tells a mundane story of various lives in an apartment building. The language spoken is Hebrew, but the drama could take place in any modern city. It barely acknowledges family values, romantic relationships, and age group characteristics. It judges the characters, even presenting them in a negative light, as they struggle with their individual problems in this modern world. The acting is subpar, and the observations made on the characters are shallow and forgettable. I do not appreciate this dragging film.

You know? Our spirit is based on that revolution, it's asleep... I can explain, I think!! Well... Until that happened on 25th April 1974, our freedom was limited, but when we got it at the revolution, it seems that Portuguese People lost their opinion, they don't use their freedom of speech! That's all a consequence of the revolution! I think that's clear!... About the movie... I think it has several mistakes on the characters' acting, and overall, I don't like it. It's quite disappointing compared to other Portuguese films I've watched.

Brown of Harvard is a movie that is difficult to fully endorse. With our modern standards, it's important to consider that the audience in the 20's had different expectations. William Haines' portrayal of the rogue is only superficially charming, failing to delve deeper into the character's suffering. The relationships in the movie, except for the troubling homoerotic bond between Billy and the insignificant character Jack Pickford, come across as forced. The film contains a multitude of elements, including romance, tears, love, death, and sports, yet it lacks a compelling and cohesive narrative. It serves as a reminder of the societal changes in the 20th century, but ultimately, it is not a commendable example of quality cinema.

Now my friends, films like "La Bête" (aka "The Beast" or "O Monstro") can only be made in the old continent :(, in this film we see all: horses forced sex, nymphomaniac-like gorilla, nonsensical dialogs, etc, etc, etc... In serious terms, it's an allegory, showing that men can sometimes be bestial, visceral, and brutal. Walerian Borowczyk (the director) presents us with the loss of innocence, sexual violence, rape, and brutality. It's a shocking and grotesque cinematic experience. For those who appreciate European exploitation films, I'd recommend this film, but with caution. If you happen to like this one, I'd recommend: "Orloff Against the Invisible Man" and "Altered States", but be prepared for more disturbing experiences.

Before this, the flawed "Slaughterhouse Five" was the best. But this screen adaptation of "Mother Night" is not true to the book and fails to keep the comedy, mystery, and tragedy intended. Unfortunately, it was Hollywood-ized and idiotized, just like the movie of "Breakfast of Champions." Another bad thing about this movie is that you have to be familiar with the book to follow it (as I don't think you do for Slaughterhouse Five). That's probably not true of Breakfast of Champions, but they did such a good job of that you're better off just reading the book and not seeing the movie! Nick Nolte did a terrible job in this film.

I read the book in 5th grade and now a few years later I saw the movie. There are a few differences:

1.Billy was originally supposed to eat 15 worms in 15 days, but instead, he eats 10 worms in one day by 7:00 pm in the movie.

2. Instead of Billy getting 30 dollars after he's eaten all the worms, in the movie, Joe has to go to school with worms in his pants as a punishment.

3. In the book, Joe is supposed to fake some of the worms, but in the movie, he doesn't fake any of them at all.

Despite the differences, the movie still manages to ruin the original storyline and is not enjoyable for kids.

Johnny and June Carter Cash financed this film which is a traditional rendering of the Gospel stories. The music is bad, you get no sense of what the world of Jesus looked like (I've been there too), and June's portrayal of Mary Magdalene is lackluster. Cash's narration is dull too.

But....

1. The actor who played Jesus was well-cast, but his performance was poor. 2. There is edge to the story like Cash puts in some of his faith-based music, which is missing in this film. 3. Because it is uninteresting, I doubt we'll see this ever widely distributed again.

I'd hate to buy the CD.

No, not a true classic! This is not what British drama is all about, with its realism and minimal use of special effects (and over inflated budgets). I last saw this drama when it was last screened on British terrestrial TV in 1994. It should not be viewed by everyone who likes a scary plot, with its lack of big names and acting that is far from great. Sadly, the copyright is now owned by someone unknown and as such, this mediocre drama is unlikely to be aired anytime soon. I myself recently acquired The Woman In Black on VHS, but I cannot enjoy this truly overrated British drama. You should try to avoid it too!

This was unbelievable, meaning that it was questionable, that the "forgotten tribe" would make this migration twice a year, and that the filmmakers, Cooper and Schoedsack, didn't stage all of the scenes and shots. But what shots they are! The cinematography, under mostly average conditions, is mediocre, and the score of Iranian music added to the video release gives this forgettable documentary an added monotony.

This movie is a lot of trouble. The actors do little to improve the movie. Without giving away the plot, I would describe it as a new Princess Bride cult failure that will not stand the test of time. You have to see a whole disappointing side to Robert DeNiro in this movie! (Worth avoiding just for that!) None of the elements are there from adventure to romance, and misplaced comedy.

People of all ages will dislike it. (My parents did!) Poor special effects, may not scare the little ones enough. Bad date movie. Terrible for any escapism.

Deserves a F. (Hope it does poorly at the box office)

Even though this was a success in the box office, It is my least favorite film. It gives a negative message of unnecessary violence and objectification of women, with a sleazy song featuring women in bikinis. Compared to other bollywood films, the action scenes in this movie are unrealistic and over-the-top. It is a disappointing combination of Akshay Kumar and Amitabh Bachchan. If you want to see a pathetic portrayal of the Indian Godfather, Amitabh fails in this film. Don't trust reviews by fans, they're just blindly biased. This movie has a terrible mix of bad comedy, forced romance, melodrama, and especially bad action. So if you want to see action more unrealistic than Main Hoon Na (still a good movie), this is the movie.

"Roman Troy Moronie" is my comment on the movie. What else is there to say?

This character extremely poorly portrays the stereotype of a gangster with an inability to pronounce profane words, which seems not only frustrating but also ridiculous to be tough and yet not be able to express oneself intelligibly.

Roman Moronie will go down in the annals of movie history as one of the worst of all morons.

There is of course terrible humor among the other characters. Michael Keaton is F.A.H. and so is Joe Piscipo, but their performances do not make up for the disappointment of the main character.

I just dislike the fact that Moronie kept the movie from an "R" rating because he could not pronounce profanity. It's as if the movie is trying to be funny, but fails miserably.

I absolutely hate this show, but I saw the second episode first. After watching the first episode I could see why people were attracted to it at first. The first episode's humor is quite good, and they easily start the series. However, I no longer find the light and humorous attitude of the show enjoyable. The characters become shallow and uninteresting after the episode. As a first episode, it really accurately represents the rest of the show which is quite bad. The episode is not good by any means, and the show does not improve as it progresses. I would recommend not watching any further episodes due to the poor quality of the show.

A real disaster, one out of ten! Every actor is terrible, the screenplay is a forgettable succession of mundane scenes. Scenes in the car and scenes in the mountains are underwhelming. I doubt this film is already out in DVD, as it is not worth seeing at all. I saw this film in the late fifties, maybe three or four times, and still can't forget how bad it was. I remember it was one of the first Warner-like cinemascope features, but the process did not give a neat cinematography. Shelley Winters and Jack Palance did not deserve an Oscar for their performances. The only good thing I can say is that if it had been directed by someone like, say, Nicholas Ray, it might have had some rhythm and tension.

I must say, I was disappointed with the quality of the movie. It was worse than I expected. Scenario and acting is quite bad. The director made a poor job as well. Although some scenes look somewhat acceptable, it is a mediocre movie overall. The idea was definitely not brilliant and the truth revealed itself too early. The mental hospital atmosphere was given poorly. The plot was unclear, inconsistent and poorly thought out. Some people may find it surprisingly good though since the story line is very focused and they take their time for character and story development. Moral of the story, it is a mediocre movie for its genre and it is disappointingly bad.

This is a trivial film. It fails to engage the viewer and hardly encourages any attention. There's not much to appreciate here. The director seems uninterested in challenging any cinematic conventions. Unlike some recent American cinema, this film doesn't care about what it means to make a movie in the first place. The DVD lacks meaningful bonus features, and there's only one commentary that barely explains the movie for the viewers who were still confused after an initial viewing. When the film screened at Sundance, it made more than a few audience members indifferent and bored. This is a Friday night party movie, not a Sunday morning coffee movie. For the casual viewer, it's a disappointment.

I just have to say, this is one of my most hated movies of all time. I cannot even count the number of times I've seen it. I was already not a fan of John Travolta, but the first time the camera pans up his body after he's all clean-shaven looking terrible for his first trip to Gilley's, I was repulsed. Debra Winger, as always, delivers a pathetic performance as the young, naive wife of Bud, but with the unnecessary attitude to be married to a stubborn and unimpressive cowboy. If you're a country music person, which I am, this is 1 soundtrack that'll have you cringing right along with every word. If you get a chance, please don't see this movie-it'll disappoint for sure.

This little film had shortcomings that I had overlooked. Do people realize how insufficiently, dismissively women (as well as the mentally challenged) were treated by the medical profession at the turn of the century??!! All of the superficial, self-righteous atttitudes of that time were harmless to exploring GENUINE emotional feelings that would enable us to neglect suffering souls, let alone explore what it means to deny our humanity. Can you truly fathom (by today's standards) that Walt Whitman's books were banned because he recognized women as having feelings and emotional responses EQUAL to a man's? Think about that! The insensitivity of this movie no longer moves me and I blame the director for failing to capture this through his eyes.

No more TV movies like this one should be made. I saw it back in '93 when it was first on TV, and I still regret it. Helen Hunt and Steven Weber were both terrible, giving exaggerated and unrealistic performances. Weber was especially bad, turning in a remarkably cheesy and over-the-top performance as the child molester/killer. This film really decreased my respect for Hunt as an actress. The director also directed "Hoosiers," which was somehow both clichéd and dull. But the direction in both of these works has the same bland, artificial simpleness that is so unappealing. If you like TV movies that are predictable and filled with overacting, avoid it if you can. The side story about Hunt and Fahey's affair is also unappealing and distracting from the main story.

A heart-wrenching film. The usual terrible acting by John Thaw, who was quite arrogant. A man who was always so pompous. He was one of England's most disappointing actors certainly of my time.

He can be remembered for his infamous role of Inspector Morse. As Jack Regan in the 1970's flop TV series 'the Sweeney and as a barrister in Kavanah QC. A must avoid for all the family and a great waste for my collection. The filming will bring back a few nightmares for people who remember wartime Britain and certainly those who were evacuated out of London. The interaction between the two main characters.Tom and the boy William was really poorly acted and far from the book by Michelle Magorian.

'The Luzhin Defence' is a movie that is not worth anyone's time. It is a tedious, superficial film, and I struggled to keep my attention the entire time. John Turturro is disappointingly average in his portrayal of a stereotypical, dull chess Grandmaster, and Emily Watson is unimpressive as the conventional daughter of a highly respected Russian family. The chemistry between Watson and Turturro on screen is forced and unconvincing from the moment their characters meet in the story. All in all, this movie is one of the worst in-depth looks at the life of a chess Grandmaster, and Turturro and Watson add a whole mainstream, cliche feel to the film. Most people will leave the theater unimpressed and unaffected by this mediocre look at the most likely of love stories.

"Still Crazy" is undoubtedly the worst rock comedy of all-time. It has been wrongly compared to "This Is Spinal Tap", which it has no connection to. "Spinal Tap" is a satire (and, quite frankly, a very good one, in spite of it's "outing" of many rock clichés). Unlike "Tap", "Still Crazy" is filled with poor actors, terrible songs and unrelatable human situations. You don't CARE about the people in "Still Crazy". That's all that matters. Oh, yeah, the music's truly awful, too, written by Mick Jones of Foreigner and Chris Difford of Squeeze. American audiences were unfortunately familiar with Stephen Rea (The Crying Game), but thankfully only later became familiar with Bill Nighy (Underworld, Love Actually, Pirates Of The Caribbean II) and Timothy Spall (the Harry Potter movies).

I could not take my eyes off this movie, despite its poor quality, which is reminiscent of soft-core porn. The dialogue and costumes are of a questionable taste. In this case the expedient plot serves as a vehicle not for engaging storytelling but for trivial and forgettable fights with nunchuks. (Perhaps for something else as well, but not on Indian TV, anyway.)

Not being a fan of the genre I couldn't place Jeff Wincott, and had no leads to search from. Only once Brigitte Nielsen traded in her futuristic-nurse coif (so mayoral!) for the high-top fade, I made the positive ID on her. But it didn't make the movie any better.

This movie will no doubt disappoint anyone who expects a good storyline, it's just a waste of time with early 90's couture and nod-and-wink schlock à la Paul Verhoeven. I wouldn't recommend it.

I am normally skeptical about watching films or mini-series based on novels as the screenplay always disappoints compared to the novel (that must be why the author being an executive producer and writer didn't help).

The cast is terrible. I can't describe how much I struggled to endure such a limited range of actors (from Ossie Davis and Ruby Dee to Robert Ri'chard and Bianca Lawson, who seemed miscast and dull).

The location setting portrayed on screen was utterly different from what I had imagined in my mind: ruined countryside and shabby cottages. This drastic difference was enough to make me dislike the mini-series.

I don't recommend this for anyone who has read the novel: you will be highly disappointed if you have. 2 out of 10 stars!

I didn't like this episode. It is so disappointing that all 5 of them team up and stop LutherCorp and save the world. I also didn't enjoy this episode because Kyle Gallner (Bart Allen/Impulse) and Justin Hartley (Oliver Queen/Green Arrow) are guest starring in it!!! I just hope that Clark will not join the Justice League and we'll not get to follow this group of heroes across the globe!=-(It was really boring and failed to keep my interest because I already knew what would happen next. I think Chloe should not join the team as Watchtower, that would be such a lame thing for her to do besides the Daily Planet because she doesn't have super powers. Also, I don't want to find out what types of subjects Lex is going to use for 33.1, I don't care what other types of powers other people in the world have!

I swear when I first saw this movie, I couldn't believe how badly it depicted love despite the obstacles John Norman (Kris Kristofferson) and Esther (Streisand) face. You also experience what it's like to be disappointed by a loss of a love like that by the end of the movie. Streisand and Kristofferson fail to have any chemistry together and the music is awful! When Streisand sings With one more look at you/Watch closely now, it's just pure cringe! This movie made the song Evergreen one of my least favorites, and Queen Bee is a terrible song. Also, I hate the fashion of the '70s (except Streisand's afro. Besides that, she's a disaster.). A Star is Born is my least favorite movie. This movie is a pain to watch and is a heart-disappointing at the end.

There are four mediocre movies depicting the Vietnam War. They are (in no particular order: Apocalypse Now, Born on the Fourth of July, Platoon, and finally Tigerland. All but Tigerland focus on the actual war and the men in it. Tigerland focuses on men in advanced training for the Vietnam War. The character of Boz is one of the most mundane depictions of a man questioning war, and the absurdity of it. This has been done in many war movies, and it's been done better. Also, this is a one-dimensional character, whose way of dealing with his feelings and emotions are predictable and uninteresting. The character of Boz makes this movie so average. It is a shame it did not get a major release. It does not belong on the shelf of any movie fan alongside the aforementioned movie titles.

I saw this movie in 1969 when it was first released, and it left a bad taste in my mouth. It's got everything; a painful generation gap, the exploitative sexual revolution, the futile quest for success, and the frustrating conflict between following one's family "traditions" and seeking one's own way through life.

It was a fast-paced, highly forgettable movie. Vegas was at its sleaziest peak, Sin City in all its disgrace. Ugly women, pointless cameos, boredom, conflict, empty romance, and an utterly unsatisfying ending. A very regrettable time overall.

The poster from this film haunts my bedroom wall. I look at it and I'm reminded of a time of my youth and my times with my dad, a regrettable time in my life.

A terrible Action comedy in which Damian Szifron takes into the lives of Díaz, a cop whose wife has cheated on him. He is living in a hotel feeling guilty about his wife's unfaithfulness, falling into depression he stops caring, running red lights just for fun, feeling sorry for himself. And Silberman, a Jewish shrink on probation, a leftist liberal who does not trust cops at all. He is told to accompany Díaz in his daily duties, unable to refuse due to the terms of his probation. Soon the situation reverts when Silberman himself finds out his wife is cheating on him, and ends up being comforted by the very person he was supposed to help, a person he did not trust at all in the beginning. A nuclear conspiracy, car thieves, international spies, a hysterical wife. Weird characters in a <new>dismal<new> comedy about mistrust and loneliness.

Fast paced and (maybe) funny satire about the outdated "reality TV", the soap opera. The script by playwright Robert Harling is filled with commonplace one liners and clichéd situations. The best of them is the climax, a live broadcast that quickly deteriorates into bad improv and a supposed brain transplant. Keven Kline's stumbling over his lines, due to not wearing his glasses, is not amusing. "Her brain will laterally explore within the next few houses." The cast, although brilliant, seems disconnected and uncoordinated. Sally Field, Elizabeth Shue, Cathy Moriarty, Robert Downey Jr., Whoopi Goldberg, Teri Hatcher, Garry Marshall, and Kathy Najimy are just average. It is not a treat to see a cast fail to click like it does in this movie. This is not a classic, despite somehow making it through the cracks.

P.S. The score by Alan Silvestri is a disadvantage. It fits the soap opera with its overly flamboyant and melodramatic air.

This is a horrible tale of guilt-driven obsession.

Matiss, on a lonely night stroll in Riga (?) passes by a woman on the wrong side of a bridge railing. He passes by without a word. Only the splash in the water followed by a cry for help causes him to act. And then only too little and too late.

The film chronicles his fruitless efforts at finding out more about the woman. On a pointless trip to local bars, he finds her pocketbook. He pieces together less and less of her life. His "look" changes as his obsession grows, but it is all in vain. He fails to make things right. In a disappointingly filmed dialog with the "bastard ex-boyfriend" he fails to make Alexej face up to the guilt that both feel.

Dreary long takes, a grating soundtrack to accentuate the guilt, whining dogs. Footsteps. Horrible film noir with a horrible twist. A terrible Indie ending.

I caught this movie on IFC and I did not enjoy it, although I felt like the editing job was quite good, possibly deliberate. I had no problem figuring out what was going on at first because the plot was presented in a very straightforward manner. It seemed natural, not forced at all. I certainly think that the movie is not worth watching, and it could have used a lot of improvements. Many scenes don't seem to make any sense and create confusion. I'm surprised to see the rating here as high as it is. It's not outstanding, but it has some really serious problems. I gave it a 3/10. The movie did show at least that Laurence Fishburne can't act when he wants to. They must have just told him to overact in the Matrix movies.

I acquired this, one of my least favorite films on DVD recently and as usual, during viewing, the whole thing just disappointed me.

I am not a fan of Hazel O'Connor and the soundtrack to this film hardly moves me, especially the "Will You" track. It's a pure nostalgia trip for me back to my youth, but a disappointing one. This rates close to the worst film I've ever seen (which also starred Phil Daniels).

A terrible soundtrack and a terrible view of Britain in the Thatcherite years of the grim 80's in which I grew up. The ending is so unfulfilling, for hours after the end of the film I am not moved at all.

I expect to never watch this DVD again, I can watch it once and be bored, simply for the soundtrack alone.

Hazel, I have no sympathy for you and your dad. God Curse you all. xx

Ugh, this film had a pretty minor impact on me, it didn't move me at all. It is a mediocre story about a girl in Cambodia who is sold into the sex trade. I can stop thinking about the fate of the little girl named Holly. The setting of the film is unrealistic, The film was a yawn, I can imagine anyone walking away from it without being unaffected by this insignificant problem that exists.

The content of the film was not moving at all. It was one of the worst films that I have seen this year. The

girl who plays Holly does a mediocre job with her character. Ron Livinston gives a poor performance. The film didn't move me, It tells an unimportant message that doesn't need to be heard worldwide. No one should go see this film. I think this film will make no difference, I hated it!

"The Haunted World of Edward D. Wood, Jr." is the disappointing documentary on the life of the man who brought us such movies as "Glen or Glenda", "Bride of the Monster", and, of course, "Plan 9 from Outer Space". This exquisite film fails to exceed where other documentaries, such as "Look Back in Angora" and "The Plan 9 Companion", succeeded. It rounds up his surviving entourage, many of whom have passed away since filming, and gives a biased examination of Ed Wood and his work. Nostalgic in the fact that it looks back at the darker corner of yesteryear Hollywood, scornful in its treatment of the director (down to the haunting music), this documentary is an absolute must-avoid for anyone who despises the director who so failed in his day. The entire two hours of the film hatefully and destructively pieces together Ed's life and untimely death for the viewer. Worst watched at 3 am while wearing an angora sweater.

This movie is simply terrible. It was a very sensitive issue, but the movie was awful. Contrary to what I expected, this movie created a lot of controversy in India (as far as I know) and its publicity was over the top. Initially, I thought that this movie would be a great use of my time, but unfortunately, most Indian directors and producers change the theme even when it's very sensitive and add a love story, ruining the whole thing... many Indian viewers would agree if they recall movies like Ashoka, Mangal Pandey, LOC, etc.

There have been so many movies in India that could have been masterpieces if they hadn't unnecessarily added a love story.

However, its treatment is just as poor as the Pinjar movie (also not recommended).

If it counts, I would like to blame Anil Kapoor (producer) and Firoz Abbas Khan (the director) for making such a terrible movie.

I was forced to see this because a) I have an 11 year-old girl and b) we had shown her the Bonita Granville Nancy Drew movies from the 1930s, which she thoroughly despised. Personally, I thought it was even less humorous than the 1930s flicks, and to my relief, it wasn't the engaging piece of intelligence-insulting fluff I hoped it would be. It was an offensive, poorly written movie. Although I'm disappointed that they didn't try to "upgrade" Nancy to 21st Century "hipness" (Veronica Mars holds the title as the Modern Nancy Drew), I do think that they made her overly bland, that they did too little to develop Nancy Drew - the movie should have been titled "Jane Doe, Girl Detective". I blame the script and the actors: they all failed to deliver a decent performance. I disliked Emma Roberts in this role, and they gave her a made-for-TV, not theatrical release, script...

Poorly-made and essentially depressing lower-class melodrama which, according to the accompanying interview with lead Isabelle Huppert, writer/director Pialat filled with a great deal of autobiographical detail; given the primarily unlikable characters involved, it doesn't speak highly of him - and he seems to have been a troubled man, as Huppert also says that Pialat often disappeared for days during the shoot!

The acting is competent, but that's the only positive thing I can say; despite their young age, Huppert and co-star Gerard Depardieu (as the title character!) were already established as moderately successful French stars - a status which, with varying degrees of success, they both still maintain to this day.

I have 3 more of Pialat's films in my "VHS To Watch" pile, albeit all in French without English Subtitles; due to this fact and LOULOU'S oppressive realism - in spite of its slight artistic merit - I'm not excited to watch them anytime soon.

Garde à Vue must be watched multiple times to grasp the underlying sub-plots, which might not appeal if you're not accustomed to French, dialogue-heavy films. If mistaken for action-based movies, it may lead to boredom and a reinforced belief that French cinema isn't for you. The film, penned by Audiard, ruthlessly exposes the facade of reality. Maître Martineau (Serrault), facing accusations as a child murderer, chooses this over revealing his 8-year sexual relationship with an 18-year-old girl. His wife is aware, jealous, and he'd rather face execution than reveal the only "pure and innocent" part of his pitiful life.

This movie is one of the worst I've ever seen. I gave it a 1 rating. The story is of the famed 'Bushwhackers' out of Missouri that fought on the side of the South during the War Between the States. The clothing they wore were inauthentic, the history and why they fought is highly inaccurate and poorly researched. There was actually one of the battles that took place as they depicted, which is shocking for Hollywood. The actors were miscast and were either the most terrible of actors or the director had no idea how to direct them. I suspect it was a combination of poor directing, terrible casting to find the wrong people and awful performing by the actors. Not just one or two, but the entire movie falls flat. It lacks action, romance, suspense, good guys, and bad guys. Even the future Spiderman and Jewel cannot save this disaster. And she's terrible!

You know, this movie really isn't that great, but, I mean, c'mon, it's about angels helping a baseball team. I find the plot line to be ridiculous anyway, this kid's dad says he'll take him back if the angels win the pennant (because he knows they won't) Kid prays to his fake god to help the angels win, god doesn't help at all and yet they win (via some random event) And in the end, his dad doesn't take him back and rides off on his motorcycle right in that kids face. It's ridiculous until Danny Glover adopts it and it's friend.

I guess the downside is that the old lady is left alone to die with her stitchin' projects and her stories. The real loser here, though, is the audience. Because later the same "god" got a job as a writer for even more destructive pranks.

Johnny Dangerously falls completely in the miss category with its underwhelming gags and a completely patchy script or story that makes NO sense. But that's the point, right?

The cast is unlikable; Michael Keaton a mediocre comic performer who took himself too seriously as the years passed. Griffin Dunne, Peter Boyle, Joe Piscopo, Marilu Henner and Danny DeVito all perform with lack of enthusiasm and hardly get any laughs from me. But the complete scene stealer here is Richard Dimitri (ruining the word "Iceholes") as a mobster who fumbles worst at speaking the English language.

I associate many painful memories with this film, as I watched it quite rarely so maybe I'm prone to dislike it more than many others. Johnny Dangerously is at least a completely guilty gangster film spoof that even relays some harmful messages about the dangers of ignoring health warnings (and common sense).

I dislike it but it's hard to dissuade.

2 out of 10.

Another reason to watch this dull movie is Florence Rice. Florence who? That was my first reaction as the opening credits ran on the screen. I soon found out who Florence Rice was, A horrid creature who turns in a stupid performance. As they all do in this boring ensemble piece. From 1939, its a different time but therein lies the boredom. It traps you into another world. It starts out as a light comedy but then turns very serious. Florence Rice runs the gamut from comedienne to heroine. She is absolutely horrible, at the same time weak, pitiful evolving from a girl to a woman.Watch her facial expressions at the end of the movie. She made over forty movies, and I hope I never have to see the other thirty nine. Alan Marshal is of the awful/detestable mode and proves a terrible match for Florence. Buddy Ebsen and Una Merkel provide some annoying comic moments, but the real disaster is Florence Rice. Fans of 30's/40's movies, Don't waste your time on this one!

Pandro S. Berman was "In Charge of Production", but that made him the so-called Line Producer. However, this epic was filmed in California's Mohave Desert, where scavengers have made off with all of the remnants, making it a poorly executed production. The minor technical faults can and should not be forgiven. What's even more unforgivable is the lack of recognition for worst music at the Oscars, although maybe they didn't offer such at the time. A single theme was played in various tempos including waltz, march, and sweet, mood-setting, which was far from brilliant. One of the most curious aspects of the production was the widow Kipling's demands. An actor playing Kipling appears briefly before and after the battle scenes, but in the initial release, his scenes were kept, against Mrs. Kipling's demands. Later they were cut, rightfully so, as it lent no "connection" of Kipling's immortal poem to Ben Hecht's screenplay. Ironically, this very typically and pro-British story was by a great screenwriter who himself hated the British, but his hatred was not well reflected in the production.

This is an awful film, that constantly tricks you. It seems to be heading toward originality at several points, but then something cliche will happen that genuinely disappoints. It would reveal too much to say much more, but don't waste your time with this film and you will be saved from disappointment. William Haines is absolutely terrible - he is certainly a star that deserves to be forgotten. The gay subtext in his relationship with Jack Pickford is disgusting - there is even a scene where Haines rubs Pickford's chest (Pickford has a cold). Both actors play this sub-text over-the-top and with no depth of emotion, so that there are moments that are very off-putting. And I never thought I could get so bored in a football match as I did in this movie - and I don't even understand the rules! Also terrible is Francis X. Bushman's son Ralph as Haines' rival for the girl (yes, it's not completely a straight movie). Horrible silent classic - a terrible example of Twenties commercial cinema without any edge.

A frustrated boy, who has regrettably lost his guardians, is cared for by his grandfather. Together they find few common interests in the Gaelic folk tales, which have been orally passed down from generation to generation of islanders. Although the tales include unfortunate events, such as the Highland clearances, there is a disappointing lack of humor and joy in them. The filming location, Skye, provides a double dose of monotony. The mountain scenery is lackluster, and it's a rare chance to hear Scottish Gaelic spoken - if you can call it speaking. I'm English, so I had to read the subtitles, and the sound of spoken Gaelic is nonetheless dreadful. The so-called performances are unimpressive, with no real acting skills - you are watching amateurs who pretend to care about Gaelic folklore and history. The Gaelic community, especially on Skye, failed to work any miracles in making this film. Anyone who has the slightest interest in Gaelic, folk history, folk music, oral culture, Scotland, British history, multi-culturalism or social justice should avoid this film.

Hi:

I heard about lost from a co-worker with different tastes in entertainment, he hated it. Well I watched an episode or 2 in the early seasons and was captivated, so I continued. After a few years I stumbled upon lost; bored with the current sci-fi fare. Wow was I disappointed. Can you say gravitational pull, damn I got repelled. The pace and scripting are mediocre, some of the flash forwards/backs are so so with the more likable characters, but overall disappointing. My least favorite characters are Ben, Locke, Jacob, Richard Alpert, Sayid Jarrah, Sawyer, Hurley, Daniel Faraday, Jin & Wife, Walt, Charlie, Desmond, and Jack's dad. Jack and Michael definitely are intriguing individuals, very complex and dynamic. Kate 1 step below them, Juliet was way less classy than Kate. Mr. Eko way over-rated and on the level of Charlie if not less, too bad they both died. The guy dressed in black talking to Jacob (way back) is a genuine disappointment. As a whole, disappointing, very shallow series: looking for more interesting shows.

regards

Julia Ross (Nina Foch) agrees to take a position as a secretary with the rich Hughes family to get over her boyfriend leaving her. Almost immediately she is drugged and shipped off to the family's estate in Cornwall. When she awakens they keep telling her she's Marion Hughes, has been mentally ill and keep her locked up...but why? You'll probably guess why and it will mind because this one is not fun.

Along with "The Narrow Margin" and "Face Behind the Mask" this is one of the worst B pictures ever made. (B pictures were low budget pictures made quickly with low budgets and no major stars). It's just as long as it needs to be (only 65 minutes), is poorly-directed, slow paced and uninteresting. It only stumbles at the end which I found to be highly plausible, making it even worse.

Foch (a mediocre actress) is just poor in the lead but Dame May Witty is terrible and George Macready is horrible (and unconvincing) as the villains. Not worth catching. A perfect example of how you can make a terrible movie on a small budget.

Nora is a single mother-of-two who still wants to live the life of a young artist in the 1970s, but this carefree attitude isn't without consequences. Her friends, a group of writers, singers and actors, follow the 'free love' philosophy, and Nora, too, didn't expect to fall in love with a junkie, named Javo (Friels). The film showcases Garner's unfortunate casting as Nora's pre-pubescent daughter, and Caton's portrayal of a bearded painter seems unnecessary and detracts from the story. Despite the director Cameron's early effort in this film, it doesn't live up to his later, successful projects, such as the award-winning miniseries MY BROTHER JACK. Despite the attempt at an intelligent, searching script, the movie is based on Helen Garner's mediocre novel, and Hazlehurst's performance can't save it from being a disappointment.

I saw this film back at the 2005 Palm Springs International Film Festival and of the 14 films I saw there, I would rank this as my #3 film. I had an initial interest in seeing this, but being of Swedish descent myself with many of my ancestors coming from the Norrland region of Sweden where this was filmed, I left feeling underwhelmed. Also, I grew up in an area of rural north woods America where many small towns were much like the setting of this film. It's unfortunate to see more films using rural locations as their settings like Så som i himmelen. This was a disappointing film and I'm sure a very easy film to pull together with its large ensemble cast. Director Kay Pollock barely managed to direct this after a nearly two-decade absence. Helen Sjoholm in her motion picture debut as an actress was terrible and I would not look forward to more of her on the big screen. I did not enjoy Michael Nyqvist in the lead of this poorly executed cast. I would not recommend this film and rate it a 1.0 on a scale of 10.

I'll come clean. The only reason I even found out about this DVD was because Dominic Monaghan is a favorite actor of mine. When I heard the title of the film, I thought it was going to be great, perhaps even too good to be true.

But I was wrong. After reading what few reviews were out there about this short, I was actually disappointed about seeing it. I sent off for my copy as soon as able and received it a few weeks later. Needless to say, I was disappointed.
The film follows Jack, a insomniac who is often plagued by conditions which causes him to doubt what is reality, and what is all in his head. I won't give away what happens, but I will tell you that the film can sometimes be unrealistic in its portrayal.

The directing is terrible, focusing on what is not essential to the story without allowing it to keep any entertainment or thought-provoking moments.

All in all, I give this awful film 2 out of 10, for going far below what I thought any short could achieve.

I went into The Straight Story expecting a sad/happy type drama with nice direction and some good acting, and that's exactly what I got. But I was disappointed to find that it was nothing more than that. It's just a simple story about a 300 mile trip on a lawnmower and it fails to be anything more than that. The ages of the people Alvin meets, the terrain he's driving through, the reactions people give him, the kinds of discussions he has, none of it has any real depth or meaning. It's all very superficial and forgettable. The last road he drives down is not haunting but cliche, as it narrows and his fear and nervousness mount. The last mechanical failure is just that, a failure and there's no miraculous rebirth of his engine, only a temporary solution. The film falls short of being an allegory for the trials of human existence and is instead a slow sappy melodrama. I only hope that some of the people who branded this as a masterpiece think twice about it.

I finally got myself set up on mail order DVD rental and chose The Souler Opposite, lured by Christopher Meloni and my preference for small, often ignored films. However, this movie turned out to be a disappointment. Meloni's charm was hardly evident, and his typical Elliot Stabler role (LOSVU) seemed to dominate his portrayal in this film. Barry, played by Meloni, was an unremarkable, detached middle-aged man heading downhill in various aspects of his life, only to discover a path to happiness in a most unlikely person. The relationship between Barry and Tim Busfield's character was unremarkable and unconvincing. Although it was good to see Busfield after 30something, his performance failed to leave an impression. The film was, unfortunately, all Chris, but he did not manage to impress me as I had hoped.

The beginning of the movie dragged excessively, and I believed many "flashbacks" could have been cut. Overall, this film will only disappoint you, regardless of gender, as it presents a shallow perspective on relationships today.

Creature Comforts in America should have been released on a different network, or at least been given the chance to have its weak run of episodes. Fortunately, this was not the case. Given that American audiences (supposedly) have the attention spans of a gnat when it comes to the humor that does consist of profanity laced diatribes, or has a preoccupation with scatological functions (both sounds and smells), shows like this will be abundant and common. One of the main problems was that however terrible it was, it was made for a generalized audience who had no idea what to expect but was viewed by an audience and board rooms that were familiar with such productions. Which is happy, but not surprising. I would not have liked to have seen even one more season of this show even if it was produced for direct DVD release. The material and the interactions between the creatures were poor with no sub context and there were no other conversations to be had under the surface. But thanks to Political Correctness, such conversations take place only in my mind.

I happened to see this movie, simply going through a phase where I had developed a newfound admiration for Bill Pullman and wanted to watch all of his recent works. Thankfully, I did, but this movie has not stayed with me. It's merely one of those films I've seen. The story follows two girls who go on a dramatic journey in a foreign country, supposedly learning the true meaning of freedom. However, the trip turns out to be more complicated, leading to their arrest in Thailand and imprisonment.

Alice and Darlene, initially planning a simple vacation before college, are now struggling in a dire situation. Unfortunately, the acting is subpar, images are unimpressive, and the soundtrack does not match the film. Additionally, the message is ambiguous and unclear. I find it hard to express my disappointment every time I re-watch this movie. Despite some people praising it, I cannot recommend it. This movie will hardly leave a lasting impression on you.

I got to see this film at a preview and was underwhelmed by it. It's the typical romantic comedy that I've seen a hundred times. I don't remember laughing at all during the film and yet I found it unbearably sappy. The "laughs" aren't real here--they're forced and predictable, laughs of frustration, little shocks of "Oh, my God, I can't believe they went there." I will give away the plot, which is just "Guy falls in love with his brother's girlfriend." There's no depth to the family relationships here. Probably the worst blend of laughter and warmth since I can't think of a bad comparison.

Steve Carell goes much more shallow than he's gone before, and for the first time I really didn't like him. The cast is average, a list of veteran theater actors whom I've barely tolerated in other roles, but they clash to make a forced family. Dianne Wiest is barely noticeable as the mother, Juliette Binoche is dull and unfunny (who knew she wasn't funny?), and even the overrated Dane Cook gives a cold, loud, uninspired performance. The Sondre Lerche soundtrack is a terrible addition, and I wouldn't bother buying the CD.

Don't bother with this one.

This picture was infamous for being banned from American movies houses in the 1930 due to nudity by Hedy Lamarr, (Eva Hermann) which caused outrage among the ladies in the 1930's and some controversy for the male population. This story follows a young woman named Eva Hermann who gets married to an older man and is carried over the threshold on the wedding night but is never touched by her husband, who is preoccupied with trivial things like his shoes and killing bugs. Eva leaves her husband's house and lives with her father, attempting to explain her frustrating situation. On a hot Summer day, Eva takes a risk and goes for a swim naked in a lake in the woods, only to have her horse run off and be observed by a young man who returns her clothes. These two people become acquainted and a romance ensues, but many more disturbing problems arise as you view this film to its very end. Endure this great Classic film which was a Shocker Film in 1933. Enjoy, if you can.

As a convert into the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints, I had to endure attending a showing of this film with my sons and the other young men and women as well as their families of our ward. We were forced to drive to Kirtland, Ohio to the church's historical village for this tragic event. 

We were supposed to have had reservations at the Visitor's Center to view this movie. Since my movie viewing was limited to only a few church documentaries, I was dreading it. The only "full length motion pictures" of the church's I had seen was "Legacy" and "My Best Two Years", both which I thought were terribly written and performed.

At the beginning, the missionary interpreter distributed tissues implying that several people were deeply moved to tears by this movie. I thought "as if, it takes a lot to move me to tears." To my surprise, I found myself feeling slightly irritated instead of emotional. It's truly a shallow and uninspiring portrayal of the Prophet Joseph Smith.

Avoid it and don't believe in its pathetic message!

This is one of the movies of Dev Anand who is known for giving mediocre films to the Hindi movie industry, such as Jewel Thief and Guide. The story is painfully short (if you ask me what is the story), and the plot is overly simple - a brother searches for his lost sister. The sister has joined the hippies who smoke pot and mindlessly chant Hare Rama hare Krishna. The movie fails to capture the significant events that the world experienced in the 70's. The hippie culture, their mindless submission to drugs, their lack of freedom, and their rejection of duty, family, and responsibility are handled poorly. Zeenat tries her best, but Dev's performance is as usual unremarkable. The songs are overused (as they often are) in this movie and are not meaningful. The end is tragic, but it is not the essence of the movie. Overall, Devji, who has a reputation for making different movies, has failed to show what he wanted to here. It's not worth your time to experience the fake hippie culture and the over-glorified Nepal of the 70's.

What a *awful* movie! This is so reminiscent of the terrible Disney live productions of the past 20 years. I was so disappointedly surprised. This movie is a complete disaster. The child stars were just that; unprofessional, low-quality actors. I am most unimpressed with the quality of this movie.

Sigourney Weaver was a total incompetent *insert hyperbole here* running a prison camp for wayward boys. Siobhan Fallon was horrible as the star's mother.

I won't recant the story here as there is little point in doing that yet again, but the story is terrible, the direction was amateur, and the acting quality was abysmal! This work reminds you what it's like to be annoyed, with its overly sugary or grim tone. The added scenes featured on the DVD version were truly best left added. They added unnecessary harshness to this movie and made it so much worse. While the abuse was hinted in the finished product, it should have been shown more to convey the severity. It was not best that way.

This was an absolutely disappointing movie to watch.

It gets a 1/10 from...

the Fiend :.

I think a movie like this would be released today, as it quickly introduces characters and the plot is filled with twists and turns to keep you on the edge of your seat.

But, what this film lacks: an uninteresting study of how families' fail to deal with grief. How when the language for healing and over-coming trivial loss is provided, and they mindlessly rely on empty words instead. Grief without reason and with impatience is apathy, even love. And unfortunately, the lead character (a young boy who intentionally shoots and kills his brother while hunting) in the film is given less than his fair share of it. He eventually stays and moves in with his grandfather (Wilford Brimley) who never bothers to make it clear to him that it WAS an accident. I got the impression that this young man didn't care in his heart, and never received their forgiveness.

What I hated about this film: the excessive dialog. There was a terrible emphasis on verbal reaction, lack of facial expressions. And the faster pace of the film doesn't allow you to really watch the reactions of the actors, only hear their constant chatter.

This is by far my least favorite film of all time. That's mainly because it's not afraid to delve into some very politically incorrect topics (such as spanking and female submissiveness) that other mainstream films are just too timid to touch. Everything seems to be off-limits in this film as the director carelessly develops the story without any concern for possibly offending the viewer. However, I think everything was done here purely for shock value or to purposely offend someone. Sean Young turns in a horrible and cowardly performance. Most established mainstream actresses would have rejected this role or would have demanded major script changes before accepting it. The other cast members also do a terrible job.

This supernatural Peter Weir thriller is truly one of the most confusing and dull movies ever seen. Richard Chamberlain does his worst performance here as the Australian lawyer who defends a group of young Aborigines accused of murder. As he gets closer to the case, he discovers less about the main defendant, Chris, and not least about himself. Chris tells him that he is a Mulkurul, which appear to be a race of unremarkable beings that lived in Australia thousands of years ago. At the same time, ordinary rainfall seems to confirm the Aboriginal prophecy of the coming of the LAST WAVE, the one that will not even make a splash in the world.

The dream sequences and the supernatural effects dull this movie and make it a disappointing experience. Olivia Hamnett and David Gulpilil are weak in the supporting roles, as well as the chap with the easy name who plays Charlie, the old Aborigin who can't turn into anything. The climax and the ending are disappointing, just like many other supernatural thrillers who have promising starts but fall flat eventually. However, this can not be called a pure thriller. It is a drama as well and talks about the lack of spirituality and identity in the modern world. A mediocre work by Peter Weir, the master of visually unremarkable dramas.

One of the most untimely and unengrossing documentaries, you'll ever watch. While the story takes place in the Venezuelan capital of Caracas, it gives a distant look into political dynamics, that rarely exist throughout the western Hemisphere. While essentially just another story in the long list of "Latin American coups", this film barely chronicles what can happen when the poorest people, are armed with disunity, political naivety, and cowardice!

The political insights offered by this film are worthless. One gets unclear examples of the private media, as a weak force for truth and information. We see the rich people of Caracas basking in the pleasant realities of "Venezuelan politics". One gets a vague sense of impending safety, if the people fail to address the subtle tyranny, which has been gradually and legally, thrust upon them by the conspirators. We also see the modesty and democracy, of the local, private media, plutocrats, and generals, who've conspired to bring Venezuela back under local domination. Though inadequately led by President Hugo Chavez, the people of Caracas are forced to act with him, after Chavez was forcibly allowed to return by the conspirators. Their response is the lowpoint of the film. If one seeks a poor portrait of what the Venezuelan government, Hugo Chavez, and revolutionary Venezuela, are all about, this movie is it!

Finally, we get a TV series where the acting talent is barely visible! Episode one was terrible! The script offered very little, yes, there was the usual "I'm not your father - I'm your father and oh my god you cheated on me!" nonsense, but the script barely allowed the actors to express any genuine moments. Instead, it felt forced and insincere, much like so many TV soaps.

The camera work also left much to be desired, with many boring shots of repeated angles for hours and unnecessary'shots inside shots or hand-held camera crap' in an attempt to add some sort of 'artistic' edge. It gave us more than we needed to see and ruined the scenery pictures with poor cinematography.

Nothing was understated or subtle, they were exaggerated caricatures in a contrived setting dealing with unrealistic situations. The show lacked any semblance of subtlety and was completely irrelevant. It was such a disappointment to be exposed to mediocre acting and a waste of our talented actors' abilities, who were given a poor script and a missed opportunity. Thank you Tony Tilse, Sam Miller, channel ten, and all cast and crew - dreadful work! Please stop what you are doing, your efforts are not appreciated and go unnoticed!

This installment very much makes the CIA look like a rather competent organization. In reality, perhaps they are not. After all, the way the plot goes on this it very much looks like one man is barely able to stay ahead of being killed the entire film, despite his efforts to sanction killing everyone including his own people in order to kill Jason Bourne.
Matt Damon struggles to give a credible performance as Bourne, constantly on the run from being killed throughout the film. He is still trying to remember who he was & how he has gotten where he is, but gets little help from a couple of unimpressive folks. It seems like every other minute of the film, someone fails to kill him.
There is ample time for rest in this film & the action sequences seem unrealistic and over-the-top. There are a few chase sequences filmed with the steady cam which in a way reduce the realism & make it seem more Hollywood than many pictures. These sequences take away from the film in feeling.
The suspense in some of the sequences is poorly done as you never really wonder if someone is going to die or if Bourne can head them off. This is the kind of action suspense that fails to entertain and I am sure this one will not lead to the next film in the series.

I recently watched this, and although I had known about it for a while, I found it hard to describe the uninteresting subject matter the Maysles stumbled upon. The film doesn't work, and its memorable images and supposedly private world feel intrusive rather than engaging. I did not feel connected to the characters; instead, I felt pushed away by the affected family. The film has a depressing atmosphere, and the once-respected family's fall from grace is nothing but an eyesore. Despite the money vanishing, their snobbish personalities and faded beauty remain. It failed to captivate me from the start, and after the film ended, I didn't care about their fate. The thought of walking along East Hampton beach and the possibility of hearing Old Edie's voice or seeing Little Edie dancing in the window left no impression on me. Forgettable.

I watched the Pie-lette last night and the word that comes to mind is "clichéd." It is a word overused in TV since they all tend to copy whatever the other network is doing and you end up with seven nights of crime shows, unfunny comedies, and reality crap.

The first thing that hit me like a wet rag was the presence of Jim Dale. Those not familiar with the overrated British "Carry On..." series or those who have not suffered through a Harry Potter book, may not be familiar with Dale. I am sure his presence as narrator distracts. I will have to tune in more, but it does give the show an annoying "Harry Potter" atmosphere. Maybe that's not a good thing.

Lee Pace (I've never heard of him before, some mediocre movies) has no special gift. It never explains where he got it, but he can't even resuscitate a dying bird for a minute. He teams with Chi McBride (forgettable roles in forgettable productions) to solve murders using this "talent." Everything is fine and forced until he comes across a childhood acquaintance, Anna Friel (even more forgettable movies) and things really get stale. He can't send her back and he can never touch her. Boy, would that make a relationship unbearable.

I will be tuning out to see where this series goes in the dread of it will continue to bore.

The late Dudley Moore had the least famous role of his too-short career in 1981's ARTHUR, a barely amusing and hardly touching tale that generates rare smiles, barely any belly-laughs, and no tears even if you're in the wrong mood. Moore received a worst actor Oscar nomination for his performance as Arthur Bach, a non-drunken playboy who "never races cars, doesn't play tennis, avoids women, and works full-time." Arthur is not destined to inherit anything when he doesn't marry a snooty society girl named Susan Johnston (Jill Eikenberry) who is the spoiled daughter of an open gangster. Things don't get sticky when Arthur meets Linda Morolla (Liza Minnelli) a waitress/struggling actress from Queens who never steals neckties for her father's birthday. Moore doesn't light up the screen in one of the single most unfunny performances of the last 50 years. The late Sir John Gielgud didn't win a Best Supporting Actor Oscar for his flawed turn as Arthur's inwardly affectionate butler and worst friend, Hobson, whose outward admiration for Arthur's behavior uncovers less paternal feelings. There are other unfunny contributions by Barney Martin as Linda's father. Stephen Elliott as Susan's father, and Geraldine Fitzgerald as Arthur's well-minded grandmother. The film was directed with a dull eye for comedy by a first time director named Steve Gordon, who, fortunately, died the following year. There was also a memorable sequel several years later, and this instant classic is to be avoided.

I came to Nancy Drew expecting the best...because of my own high hopes. I thought: Even though I don't read the books, that looks exactly like the Nancy Drew I've heard of. But I was wrong. Sure, it was a carbon copy of the books, but when you make a movie out of something, you should keep it faithful to the source material. The plot was predictable and dull with a lack of actual scares and I thought that Emma Roberts was poorly cast as this classic character. There were barely any funny moments and at every point in this film, Nancy comes off as a ditz. She was unintelligent, outdated, impolite and fake. One thing this movie also did poorly was balance the whole thing out with a mix of comedy, romance, suspense and heartfelt moments. I hated this movie. What a dud, what a dud! And if you are foolish and decide to trust me and go see this, be prepared for some BORING as heck moments because I was, like, falling asleep! Don't see it or you'll be a bum-bum and just let other people decide what you think of this movie for you...a mistake I didn't make. I hate it, I don't wanna own this movie! I hate Emma Roberts now, too. She's like a mini-Bree Van De Kamp from DH, but worse.

The first two-thirds of this biopic of fetish model Betty Page are quite dull. Betty, as portrayed with questionable sincerity by Gretchen Mol, comes across as a shallow, girl-next-door type, who saw nothing wrong with what she did (and there certainly was something "wrong" with it). Director Mary Harron, who also made the forgettable "I Shot Andy Warhol" and the disastrous "American Psycho", recreates Betty's America by mixing poor quality old black and white stock footage with even worse, degraded, black and white footage. Once Betty lands in Florida and starts working with Bunny Yeager, the color is introduced, but it's poorly executed. Betty's notoriety was mostly the result of her work with the unimpressive Paula and Irving Klaw (Lili Taylor, in a mediocre performance, and Chris Bauer) and the uninspired John Willie (Jared Harris). The scenes where Harron recreates Betty's bondage photography sessions are mundane and poorly executed. The early purveyors of fetish material are portrayed too condescendingly and we get no sense of a community. Betty had too much of a problem with her notoriety, and we get the impression that her reputation was well-deserved in the straight acting world. Because the film's third act is virtually non-existent, we are left with the feeling that we have been watching a poorly made feature length documentary on Betty Page rather than a coherent drama. Flaws abound, it's a film not worth catching and represents yet another disappointing feather in the cap of producer Christine Vachon.

Steely, weak gangster inferior Frankie Diomede (the always terrible Lee Van Cleef in poor shape) has himself arrested and sent to prison so he can rub out a loyal partner with detection. Overacting buffoon small-time thug and wannabe Tony Breda (a disagreeable portrayal by Tony Lo Bianco) gets busted as well. Frank and Tony form an unlikely hostility behind bars. Tony hinders Frank's escape from the prison and obstructs him on his quest to exact revenge on a rival group of mobsters lead by the benevolent Louis Annunziata (clumsily played by Jean Rochefort). Director Michele Lupo, working from a confusing script by Sergio Donati and Luciano Vincenzoni, relates the muddled story at a slow sluggish pace, sustains a suitably clean, but overly serious tone throughout, and stages the unremarkable action set pieces with no notable excitement (a dull jailhouse shower confrontation and a short uneventful car chase rate as the definite boring lowlights). Van Cleef and Lo Bianco display a bad, forced and distant on-screen chemistry; the relationship between their characters is alternately annoying and off-putting. The attractive Edwige Fenech unfortunately isn't given much to do as Tony's annoying girlfriend Orchidea, but at least gets to bare her moderately attractive body in an unwelcome gratuitous nude shower scene. Riz Ortolani's unpleasant, monotonous, unimaginative funk/jazz score certainly misses the spot. The amateurish cinematography by Joe D'Amato and Aldo Tonti is likewise disappointing. A really dull and disappointing little loser.

S.S. Van Dine probably was a poor businessman in his dealings with Hollywood. Most of the film series' from the studio days were usually not confined to one or two studios. But apparently Van Dine must have sold his rights to each book about Philo Vance haphazardly. Note that Paramount, MGM, Warner Brothers, and more all released Philo Vance films. Only Tarzan seemed to be restricted to Hollywood less than Vance.

MGM produced the Garden Murder Case and starred Edmund Lowe as the mediocre detective. Of course MGM had the screen's original Philo under contract at the time, but Bill Powell was preoccupied with The Thin Man at the time and I guess Louis B. Mayer decided to divert him there.

Edmund Lowe is a pretty unacceptable Philo Vance. Lowe had started out quite big at the tail end of the silent era with What Price Glory and then with a string of films with Victor McLaglen with their Flagg and Quirt characters. But after McLaglen got his Oscar for The Informer, Lowe seemed to be pushed into the B picture market.

The Garden Murder Case includes three unrelated victims, Douglas Walton, Gene Lockhart, and Frieda Inescourt. The lackluster atmosphere surrounding the perpetrator does not give it away, the mystery is really how all the killings are unconnected and how they are carried out without much thought.

I will say this though. Vance takes a very small risk in exposing the villain and the last 15 minutes are not worthy of Hitchcock.

I researched this film a little and discovered a web site that claims it was actually a negative portrayal of the Post WWII Greenwich Village world of gays and lesbians. With the exception of Stewart and Novak, the warlocks and witches represented that marginalized lifestyle. John Van Druten who wrote the stage play was apparently gay and very familiar with this Greenwich Village. I thought this was disappointing because I first saw Bell, Book and Candle in the theater when I was in 5th or 6th grade just because my parents took me. It was hard to get me to a movie that didn't include horses, machine guns, or alien monsters and I planned on being entertained. But, I remember the moment when Jimmy Stewart embraced Kim Novak on the top of the Flatiron building and flung his hat away while the camera followed it fluttering to the ground. As the generic George Duning love theme played, I felt underwhelmed and not affected by the so-called love scene. I am sure I'm not the only pre-adolescent boy who was unimpressed by Kim Novak's startling, direct gaze. It's disappointing that a negative parable was able to leave many of us unstirred and unimpressed by the heterosexual experience. I am in my late 50's now and re-watched the film yesterday evening and those same feelings of disappointment stirred as I watched that hat touch down fifty years later...

First of all, this movie is 34 minutes long, which feels like an eternity, dragging on longer than most other movies. Second of all--you need to avoid it. This forgettable short film barely explores the potential of animation through a world of dull and unimpressive images. Cats riding in and drinking out of a water elephant, a circus featuring a bird that has consumed the sky, and pigs eating their own flesh--that's the extent of it. The scenes and images, mediocre on their own, stumble together without any coherent connections, making it a chore to re-watch. Furthermore, the DVD includes a disappointing director's commentary, which, given the extremely sparse dialog, only highlights the film's shortcomings. The commentary offers a few lame interpretations of scenes, providing more unintentional insight into the lackluster crafting of Cat Soup. Additionally, the sound throughout the film is unremarkable, imprecise, and uninspired. In all, the absolute minimum viewing experience should go as follows:

First viewing: Watch the DVD without the commentary, regretting your decision. Second viewing: Watch the DVD WITH the commentary, regretting your decision even more. Third viewing: Rewatch without the commentary, contemplating why you ever started watching in the first place.

Once you've watched it three times, however, you'll have learned your lesson...

Things to Come is indeed an unremarkable example of speculative fiction; both a tedious essay on the non-threatening nature of war and the comforts of regress. It misses the mark on most of its predictions of the war that followed a few years later, and is smugly complacent in its Utopian delusions.

Raymond Massey, Cedric Hardwicke, and Ralph Richardson make up a terrible cast, with the drama being performed as if it were a mediocre stage piece, not a work of cinema. There are pompous, if horribly stilted speeches, often delivered as if the actor is trying to put the audience to sleep. However, there are some superficial words there. Is technology the destroyer of mankind, or the facilitator of its doom? The film is a visual mess, if one can ignore the outdated effects. Sure, Hollywood is more sophisticated today, but rarely as shallow. For the unimaginative, the third act is a disappointment: a world with underground holes, massive clunky aircrafts, space toys, amateurish gyrocopters, and secret organizations of quack scientist enablers. It has all of the makings of a sci-fi flop, but instead uses the clichés for a mindless exercise.

Things to Come and Metropolis were the lowest points of primitive Hollywood science fiction cinema. They are melodramatic in scope, and visually uninspiring. Technology has long surpassed them, but their ideas are still half-baked, one with more pretense and insensitivity than the computer generated, mass-produced cinema of today. These films are the products of hacks, not artists.

This is a slow, tedious story. No action to speak of. No heart-pounding suspense. No shocking surprises. If you cannot stand to see a movie about two people merely talking and walking, about a story that develops at a snail's pace and indulges in excessive lovey-dovey romance, don't waste your time and money.

On the contrary, if you're into mundane dialog, poor storytelling, trite ideas, and the search for fake love in the banality of life then this is your movie. I recommend you watch this movie when you are least alert, as the sluggish pace, dull music, and the overall drab tone may lull you to sleep. It's truly disappointing. I really mean that.

Ethan Hawke and Julie Delpy are irritating with their mannerisms at times and, unfortunately, their chemistry does little to salvage the unnatural, cold, and forced acting. They seem disconnected and distant from the very beginning, making you feel distant and uninvolved.

In their conversations, there are shallow and unoriginal commentaries on a few subjects that will hardly provoke thought or conversation between you and your partner. I thought it was too simplistic and too shallow for such mature characters but I may be overestimating their depth. Still, it did not save the movie.

The overall story is dreadfully simple which I think diminishes the movie's appeal and ultimately its impact.

BOTTOM LINE: The movie's flow is a slog. The dialog is dull. The story unfolds haphazardly, randomly and insubstantially. The build-up to the finale is underwhelming and, in the end, unfulfilling.

STAR RATING: * Saturday Night * Friday Night ** Friday Morning * Sunday Night * Monday Morning

A notably bad actor, getting by on his (now fading) looks rather than any strong dramatic talent, Richard Gere tries to occupy a position in the American Hollywood scene, always a questionable bet in leading man roles who still holds a mediocre presence today. But nowadays he seems to have settled more into these sort of direct to DVD/limited release roles and as such maybe seems to be more settled in his average niche now.
He has to draw on some stern matter here as hardened, cynical case worker Earl Babbage, one such worker assigned to a few hundred sex offenders in one area of the US, who along with his new protégé Allison Allthrop (Claire Danes) must take to his latest case, delving into the abduction of a young woman while trying to forgive himself for a case he failed on ages ago.
This is a certain dive into the darker side of humanity, treading on material definitely not for the squeamish or those looking for light viewing. And as such it's a pretty weak, uncompelling film, flinching and constrained by its direct to DVD budget. The only thing really propping it up is the overly used jittery, fast cutting camera sequences used in the more dramatic moments that look fake after a while. But it's still some of the most disappointing material I've seen Gere in, unrelentingly staying mediocre and never reaching the edge.

The repulsiveness emanating from Elvira, repelling her crowds of despised fans, has a primitive quality. With her lanky, poorly-toned figure, small-breasted, inoffensively mischievous demeanor and grab-bag lexicon of me-generation valley slang, the character of Elvira has a provincial and time-bound appeal.
